Dear Team Julia and fellow JSoC members,

I'm Anantha Rao, currently a third year BS-MS student at IISER Pune. I have been an active contributor to <https://github.com/JuliaDynamics/|JuliaDynamics> (contributed to version 1.26 of <https://github.com/JuliaDynamics/ChaosTools.jl|ChaosTools>) and I'm writing this message to share my draft proposal for GSoC-2021. I'll be working on adding additional features to compute _nonlinear local lyapunov exponents_ and the _Kolmogorov-Sinai Entropy_ for chaotic time-signals during the summer. I have written a draft proposal under the guidance of my mentor <@U8J1KET6K> and looking forward to your comments/suggestions/tips.

Link to the proposal <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1_juNi6s4stMRr-Xa23usxV9ENJp5Po576BOQk-rvhAE/edit?usp=sharing|here>

Thank you for your time !

I like your abstract very much and having a JuliaDynamics section is great.
It might be a good idea to have something visual within the dense math explanation so people feel less lost.
If you could make a small graph that shows how that linear error analysis can give really wrong results compared to nonlinear with some graph and description that highlights that an idea (I'm not sure is relevant or mathematically true)
Compare non linear with linear on an inverse pendulum (with friction) in top position. Linear lyapunov bound says I'm going to fall faster and faster for ever, non linear might be aware of boundeness or eventual convergence (not sure about that).
